data.description:
My best friend Arthur Dent and I have a crazy way
of writing messages of any kind to each other: Instead of words,
our e-mails and WhatsApp messages only contain
numbers.

Last night, for example, I received the following (extremely short)
message from him, when I asked him which movie we would like to see at our
next movie night:

```text
2 0 50 99 92 55 3 1
```

After decoding this message (it read "42"), it was clear to me
that he wanted to watch our favorite movie again:
"The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy".

You probably want to learn how we encrypt and decrypt our messages,
so here is a short explanation of what these numbers mean in detail:

The first number (2) is the size of a table, in which we write all
the characters of a message. This table is always
square, so that it initially looks empty as follows:

```text
 +---+---+
 +   +   +
 +---+---+
 +   +   +
 +---+---+
```

The following number (0) represents the start of our (admittedly quite simple)
encryption algorithm: On the first character in our table this number 0 is
added, then 1 to the second, 2 to the third and so on.

The next numbers (as many as the table has cells)
are then our encoded characters themselves, where we have used Unicode to
get the character of every number:

```text
50 99 92 55
```

They have to be interpreted as follows:

```text
2 -> 50 + 0 = 50
b -> 98 + 1 = 99
Z -> 90 + 2 = 92
4 -> 52 + 3 = 55
```

Which results in the following table:

```text
+---+---+
+ 2 + b +
+---+---+
+ Z + 4 +
+---+---+
```

The remaining numbers (3 1) are our actual message.
We use a cursor that starts at the top left corner cell of the table. Each
number indicates how many cells we have to move it line by line.
If we leave the table at the bottom right, we start
again at the top left.

So number 3 moves the cursor down to the right to the number "4"
and the last number 1 finally pushes it back up to the left to the "2",
resulting in the message "42".

By the way, I answered Arthur as follows:

```text
6 0 106 112 105 72 112 114 107 49 81 119 96 127 122
118 131 85 137 121 90 89 140 110 134 137 140 125 134
145 74 113 63 63 84 101 90 132 29 8 24 10 17 15 3 33
27 6 13 23 3 18 32 22 16 6 25 25 7 33 5 31 21 32 14
```

"Today 8 p.m. in the galaxy!"

## Tasks and Hints

- Your task is to write the decoding code for a given array
  of integer values.
- The tests will never contain incomplete or incorrect
  messages, so you don't have to write tests that will
  throw exceptions.
- All given numbers are positive or zero. No negative
  numbers are used.
- Hidden tests contain random message tests with big tables.
- The initial code contains a method "printTable" which
  you can use to print a quadratic char[][] table if this
  could be helpful for you.
